title: How to Make Non Toxic Cast Iron Burner Cleaner

steps.headline: Evaluate the food/grease build up on the stove.
Look for rust and/or wear and tear.
steps.description: Before you actually clean, make sure you can salvage the burners. In some cases, you may want to just replace the burners instead of going through the work of cleaning them.

steps.headline: Combine 3 quarts of water with 3 tablespoons of washing soda.
steps.description: Use a large, non-aluminum stock pot to combine your ingredients.

steps.headline: Remove all but one burner.
steps.description: If possible, find a burner that doesn’t need to be cleaned. If all need cleaning, leave one burner to be cleaned last. You will need to boil the water and washing soda for this project.

steps.headline: Place stock pot on the stove and turn knob to high.
steps.description: You want the water to come to a rolling boil so have patience. Check water or stay nearby to avoid having the water overflow onto the stove.

steps.headline: Submerge burners in the boiling water and simmer for several minutes.
steps.description: You can reduce the heat to a simmer while the burners are in the water but check to make sure the debris is lifting while they are “cooking.”

steps.headline: Remove burners from pot using metal tongs and place in the sink.
steps.description: Rinse burners with cool water and inspect them. Make sure all of the food has been removed or can easily be wiped off. If you still have stubborn build up or grease, fire up the stock pot and bring to a boil. Add the burner to the boiling water and boil for another few minutes. Remove and inspect. Repeat as necessary.

steps.headline: Dry burners thoroughly before replacing on stove.
steps.description: You never want to reconnect wet burners with a stove--you could become injured.

text:
Remove Excess Debris Evaluate the food/grease build up on the stove. Before you act, determine how you should best approach the situation. In most cases you will want to remove excess build up before getting down to the actual cleaning and polishing part. Run your fingernail along the top of the burner to see if you can easily pull up debris. If so, take a soft, dry cloth and chip away at the grease/food coating. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/cc/Make-Non-Toxic-Cast-Iron-Burner-Cleaner-Step-1Bullet1.jpg/v4-459px-Make-Non-Toxic-Cast-Iron-Burner-Cleaner-Step-1Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/cc/Make-Non-Toxic-Cast-Iron-Burner-Cleaner-Step-1Bullet1.jpg/v4-759px-Make-Non-Toxic-Cast-Iron-Burner-Cleaner-Step-1Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Determine if you have stubborn build up. In this case you will need to find tools to help you remove it such as steel wool pads and even a small knife (in extreme cases). Rub the pads along the stubborn build up and carefully chip away using your knife until build up has lifted. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f4/Make-Non-Toxic-Cast-Iron-Burner-Cleaner-Step-1Bullet2.jpg/v4-459px-Make-Non-Toxic-Cast-Iron-Burner-Cleaner-Step-1Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f4/Make-Non-Toxic-Cast-Iron-Burner-Cleaner-Step-1Bullet2.jpg/v4-759px-Make-Non-Toxic-Cast-Iron-Burner-Cleaner-Step-1Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Look for rust and/or wear and tear. Before you actually clean, make sure you can salvage the burners. In some cases, you may want to just replace the burners instead of going through the work of cleaning them. Create Non-Toxic Cleaner Combine 3 quarts of water with 3 tablespoons of washing soda. Use a large, non-aluminum stock pot to combine your ingredients. Remove all but one burner. If possible, find a burner that doesn’t need to be cleaned. If all need cleaning, leave one burner to be cleaned last. You will need to boil the water and washing soda for this project. Place stock pot on the stove and turn knob to high. You want the water to come to a rolling boil so have patience. Check water or stay nearby to avoid having the water overflow onto the stove. Submerge burners in the boiling water and simmer for several minutes. You can reduce the heat to a simmer while the burners are in the water but check to make sure the debris is lifting while they are “cooking.” Remove burners from pot using metal tongs and place in the sink. Rinse burners with cool water and inspect them. Make sure all of the food has been removed or can easily be wiped off. If you still have stubborn build up or grease, fire up the stock pot and bring to a boil. Add the burner to the boiling water and boil for another few minutes. Remove and inspect. Repeat as necessary. Dry burners thoroughly before replacing on stove. You never want to reconnect wet burners with a stove--you could become injured. Finished.
